docs.lead_paragraph: More than 150,000 additional low-income children and parents will receive low-cost, federally subsidized health insurance, known as FamilyCare, under a bill signed yesterday by Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, left. The law also provides for more streamlined enrollment procedures and better ways to keep children insured through the system. The FamilyCare program covers children in families earning up to 350 percent of the federal poverty level of $19,350 for a family of four, and it reaches parents whose incomes are too high for them to be eligible for Medicaid but too low for them to afford private insurance. In 2002, the state froze enrollments for parents. This year, said Kevin M. Ryan, the state's child advocate, 106,000 children and 97,000 adults are in FamilyCare. Tina Kelley (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Low-Income Health Insurance Expanded

docs.snippet: More than 150,000 additional low-income children and parents will receive low-cost, federally subsidized health insurance, known as FamilyCare, under a bill signed yesterday by Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, left. The law also provides for more...

byline.original: By Tina Kelley (NYT); Compiled by John Sullivan

docs.lead_paragraph: A commission created by New York State to reorganize its hospital system took a broad view of its mandate yesterday at its first meeting, with its chairman saying that simply closing down hospitals would not be enough to solve the current financial crisis. Although the commission will almost certainly recommend widespread closings, the chairman, Stephen Berger, said it would also look at consolidating areas of specialty in certain hospitals to provide more expertise and to prevent duplication of care, even if doing so means more travel for patients. In the past, health officials have tried to confine certain procedures like organ transplants to specific hospitals, but a variety of issues, including patient demand, made that goal hard to achieve.

headline.main: Broad Changes Sought to Solve Hospital Crisis

docs.snippet: Although the commission will almost certainly recommend widespread closings, its chairman said it would also look at consolidating areas of specialty in certain hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: As she gears up her re-election campaign for the United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton is presenting a side of herself that might have given some of her supporters great pause just a few years ago. Nothing captures this new face of Hillary Clinton better than the Web site her campaign started this week: It portrays her robust stand on national defense and her desire to reduce the number of abortions, among other positions. In fact, in the last few months, Mrs. Clinton has repeatedly confounded the expectations of people who judged her from her White House years. She has appeared publicly with Newt Gingrich, her onetime political foe. She has called abortion a ''sad, even tragic choice.'' She has stood fast in defense of her vote authorizing President Bush to go to war in Iraq. Over the last few weeks, she has found defenders among prominent conservative commentators who feel she was maligned in a new unauthorized biography.

headline.main: The Evolution of Hillary Clinton; From Seeking Major Change at Once to Taking Small Steps

docs.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton is presenting a side of herself that might have given her supporters great pause just a few years ago.

multimedia.credit: Hillary Rodham Clinton is presenting a side of herself that might have given her supporters great pause just a few years ago. The Times's Patrick D. Healy reports.
multimedia.caption: Taking Small Steps

byline.original: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ and PATRICK D. HEALY

docs.lead_paragraph: The Internet Archive was created in 1996 as the institutional memory of the online world, storing snapshots of ever-changing Web sites and collecting other multimedia artifacts. Now the nonprofit archive is on the defensive in a legal case that represents a strange turn in the debate over copyrights in the digital age. Beyond its utility for Internet historians, the Web page database, searchable with a form called the Wayback Machine, is also routinely used by intellectual property lawyers to help learn, for example, when and how a trademark might have been historically used or violated.

headline.main: Keeper of Expired Web Pages Is Sued Because Archive Was Used in Another Suit

docs.snippet: The Internet Archive, which stores snapshots of ever-changing Web sites, is on the defensive in a legal case that represents a strange turn in the debate over copyrights.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten thousand dollars once seemed a lot to pay for a few months' supply of a drug. No more. Avastin. Erbitux. Gleevec. Herceptin. Rituxan. Tarceva. These are among the first in a wave of new drugs giving hope to millions of cancer patients by treating the disease in new ways, like blocking the blood vessels that feed tumors.

headline.main: Cancer Drugs Offer Hope, but at Huge Expense

docs.abstract: New drugs that are giving hope to millions of cancer patients are hugely expensive, costing up to $100,000 over few months, hundreds of times the cost of older, more toxic drugs; new drugs, except for very successful leukemia drug Gleevec, help patients only marginally, prolonging life by few weeks or months; doctors and economists say new therapies will further fuel runaway medical costs and force difficult choices about access; table of costs for Erbitux, Avastin, Herceptin and Tarceva; photo of Shawnette Treat, Arkansas patient whose drug costs $90 a day; Dr John Hornberger of Stanford notes that US policy-makers, unlike those in Britain, do not measure cost-effectiveness of new drugs, do not control prices and bar Medicare from basing coverage decisions on cost (M)
docs.snippet: At $10,000 or more per month, new cancer therapies may further fuel runaway health care costs and block some people from being treated.

multimedia.credit: At $10,000 or more per month, new cancer therapies may block some people from being treated.
multimedia.caption: The Cost of Cancer Drugs

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: At $10,000 or more per month, new cancer therapies may block some people from being treated.

docs.lead_paragraph: The small towns are worn, like the pocket of a catcher's mitt that is the Gulf of Mexico, where bad storms slap to a stop. The day after Hurricane Dennis came and swiftly went, people hurried home just as quickly, from the couches of Alabama relatives and Georgia in-laws. They found, in most cases, their property strewn with branches and leaves, but blessedly whole.

headline.main: Most Floridians Find Branches Down but Properties Blessedly Whole

docs.snippet: Damage from Hurricane Dennis was bad, but nothing like last year's devastating Hurricane Ivan.

multimedia.credit: Damage from Hurricane Dennis was bad, but nothing like last year's devastating Hurricane Ivan.
multimedia.caption: Flooding, But Little Fury

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Damage from Hurricane Dennis was bad, but nothing like last year's devastating Hurricane Ivan.

multimedia.credit: Many of the same areas hit hard by Hurricane Ivan lastyear were hit again Sunday by Hurricane Dennis.
multimedia.caption: Struck Again

legacy.MultimediaSummary3: Many of the same areas hit hard by Hurricane Ivan lastyear were hit again Sunday by Hurricane Dennis.

byline.original: By MICHAEL WILSON; Andrew C. Revkin contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: The 228th annual session of the New York State Legislature closed in an unusually orderly fashion here on June 24, just a day later than it was scheduled to, after lawmakers who had been stung by criticism of Albany's ways took steps to try to shore up public confidence in state government. It was in many respects an atypical session. The three men who control state government -- Gov. George E. Pataki; the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno; and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver -- made a show of trying to negotiate the budget in public, for a change. They passed the budget on time -- more or less -- for the first time in 21 years. And they also worked together to shine more light on actions taken by public officials and lobbyists.

headline.main: On-Time Budget Heads List of Actions Taken in Legislature's 228th Session

docs.snippet: The session closed in an unusually orderly fashion after lawmakers took steps to try to shore up public confidence in state government.

byline.original: By AL BAKER and MICHAEL COOPER

docs.lead_paragraph: GREG AND LINDA JOHNSON thought that they had allowed plenty of time to find new health insurance last year. They were losing coverage at the end of December, so they started looking after Labor Day. ''We thought three to four months would be plenty,'' Mr. Johnson said. They quickly learned otherwise.

headline.main: Solo Health Insurance: Possible, Yes, but Not Easy

docs.lead_paragraph: Alexandra Lyon, the daughter of Judith Lyon and Anthony Lyon, both of Bethesda, Md., was married last evening to Jonathan Sondik Perelman, a son of Abby and A. Steven Perelman of Avon, Conn. Rabbi Howard S. Herman officiated at the St. Regis Hotel in Washington, with Rabbi Andrew Koren, a cousin of the bride, assisting in the ceremony. Mrs. Perelman, 29, is an English teacher at Baruch College Campus High School in New York. She graduated from New York University and received two master's degrees, in English education and in health and behavioral studies, from Columbia. Her father is the owner of Lyon Automotive Service in Bethesda. Her mother is a yoga instructor at the Sun and Moon Yoga Studio in Arlington, Va.
docs.snippet: Alexandra Lyon and Jonathan Perelman were married on Saturday in Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: MOST grade-school children are ecstatic when they fly out the doors on the last day of school. But that wasn't the case last month for more than 500 children at St. Bernard in Levittown, the School of the Holy Spirit in New Hyde Park and St. Joachim in Cedarhurst. These schools join the 22 Catholic schools in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens that are being closed for good. Finances are to blame, at least on Long Island. The elementary schools just can't afford to operate any longer on the $3,000-per-child average annual tuition. The money the churches need to cover operating costs, teachers' salaries and rising health insurance premiums far surpasses the money coming in. And that's understandable considering that it costs about $15,000 a year to educate a public school student in Nassau County and about $13,600 in Suffolk.
docs.snippet: Parents of parochial students shouldn't pay school taxes.
